snippet: There were mixed feelings in Pakistan as speculation grew that the teenager, who was shot by the Taliban for championing education for girls, might win a Nobel.
abstract: Residents of Pakistan's Swat Valley express cynicism and lack of support for Malala Yousafzai, young women's rights advocate who was shot in head by Taliban; many fear that attention to Yousafzai, who was nominated for Nobel Peace Prize, could drag retribution from Taliban, while others are motivated by resentment or even jealousy.

byline.original: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
byline.contributor: Salman Masood reported from the Swat Valley, and Declan Walsh from London. Zia ur-Rehman contributed reporting from Karachi, Pakistan, and Waqar Gillani from Lahore, Pakistan.

lead_paragraph: There were mixed feelings in Pakistan as speculation grew that the teenager, who was shot by the Taliban for championing education for girls, might win a Nobel.

headline.main: Pakistani Girl, a Global Heroine After an Attack, Has Critics at Home
headline.print_headline: Pakistani Girl, a Global Heroine After an Attack, Has Critics at Home
